text: Hey guys! Good morning!
Is anyone here using the standard Facebook login button inside an Ember App?
Yesterday I had I issue with that… sometimes the button gets loaded sometimes no
this is pretty strange, and make me think about “timing issue”: something like the FB SDK try to find the button div in the dom while it is not loaded in the page already.
Any idea?
that sounds like something worth looking into - could you move the FB SDK call into `didInsertElement`?
have you tried running it inside an Ember run?
how does the FB SDK loaded callback work? does it call a global function on the page or something?
`window.fbAsync = function() { ... }`
<@U043951H9>: yes added it to Ember.run(‘afterRender’) but nothing changed
<@U03V8V08M>: I’m initialing it this way <https://github.com/pitchtarget/ember-cli-facebook-js-sdk/blob/master/addon/services/fb.js#L23>

text: right
so I’d imagine when Facebook’s client library finishes loading it searches the DOM for stuff it can "bring to life"
but — if that stuff weren’t in the DOM yet…
so you navigate to the route _after_ FB has already loaded
then it won’t do the searching
but maybe that addon is designed to take care of that… I’m not sure
I remember being in situations like this before and needing to call `FB.XFBML.parse();` to get it to do a fresh search of the DOM

Anyone know of a project which will allow me to quickly create a CRUD app to collect data? I need to grab some multi dimensional data from news articles and don’t quite know the schema yet so it needs to be pretty easy to add new tables etc
Thinking about using ember-admin with some sort of easy backend firebase style
yeah I’d be tempted for that and ember model fragments
Any recommendation on the backend. Tempted to go with parse-server as that seems best maintained
ive been meaning to play more with <https://rethinkdb.com/blog/horizon-release/>
<http://horizon.io/>
<@U043951H9>: great. Join the party. Oh and try out ember-horizon :)
I'm working on dockerizing a full arch around this
o nice

<@U072M1BRV>: was on my phone earlier and now see that you were initially asking the question which lead to `<http://horizon.io|horizon.io>`. From the little you’ve stated it seems it might be a good fit. Ping me if you want to talk through it.
<@U04BD6KB1>: Looks ideal but ideally want somethign self hosted
yeah i can understand that; what about firebase then?
<@U04BD6KB1>: Tempted by pouch/couch db
can you self host firebase
you sure can
ah nice
couldn’t last time I checked
and it integrates with Ember very nicely
oh sorry … self-host … i had what you were saying backwards
Horizon is self-host
pouch/couch is nice for the offline capabilities
but Horizon is promising to add this in due course
if you want to get off to a quick start I’d say Horizon is a very good self-host solution
right ok. The offline capabilities aren’t important
and the fact that it can be made into an npm dependency means you can extend to do whatever you like
its just for an internal project to capture some data. Flat file documents just aren’t working so a little app is probably most appropriate
Well give it a quick spike; I think it could be a good fit for you
happy to help if I can
cheers. What made you choose Horizon at lifegadget?
well i was steering toward Mongo (away from Couchbase) but saw some favourable comparisons wrt to performance and operational overhead with RethinkDB so I gave Horizon a look.
Horizon is still a bit green but it’s moving fast
and the kind of project you’re talking about sounds like a good fit
my final decision came from the ability bypass Horizon with Express if I need to
though my initial requirements are low they’ll get more significant over time
good activity on their slack channel too
if you do choose horizon, i may ask for 15 minutes of your time in a few weeks to run past my Docker stuff past you
sure ok
looks like an interesting project. Even if I don’t use it for this I have something else in mind I can use it on too

I think the benefit of starting with a very low-friction backend (almost like mirage but actually being a server-hosted database) feels very attractive to me. Then, as the solution starts to take greater form and sophistication, having a path that allows movement on the server side … I’m sure that’s a bit too rosy a picture but it feels like a good ideal to aim for.
I’m really impressed with Firebase too but proprietary lock-in and limited flexibility on the server-side make me isolate to far fewer use cases.
ironically the “real-time” nature of both really isn’t a requirement for me but is none-the-less kinda cool
What made you choose it over couch?

just to be clear it was “couchbase” not “couchdb” … that aside, good question … I’d characterise as follows:

- I was making some other arch changes so the cost of change was lower than had been
- I had been annoyed at the overly corporate focus of couchbase (versus startup and OSS)
- As you may know — despite the name — couchbase originates from memcached and maybe as a side effect the stack pushes you toward are very hardware and memory heavy footprint
- I had originally been interested in embracing JSON-API standard so I saw Mongo in conjunction with **Fortune.js** as a nice pairing
- While coachbase documentation is good enough — largely because of its lack of OSS acceptance — there is very little 3rd party documentation and I wanted to read more on architectural decisions (found some great material for Mongo if you’re interested)
